name: Whiskey Glass
description: A spirits glass, decorated with old-fashioned crisscross patterns. It is dirty, with murky residue along the lip.
commentary: If there was ever a time to have a drink, it’d be now.

name: Playing Cards
description: An ordinary set of black and red playing cards. They appear used, showing the typical wear on the edges and tarnishing on the faces.
forensics: Fingerprints were found on the cards. They belong to Professor Bates.
commentary: Looks like things weren’t coming up aces for Thompson.

name: Newspaper
description: An incomplete crossword puzzle spreads across the front page.The writer’s solutions are barely legible, with letters of varying sizes filling each box.
forensics: Heavy pen markings litter the newspaper. The current year is circled: 1937.
commentary: 7 across is death. Someone at the tabloids must be upset.

name: Suicide Note
description: A haphazard, frantic farewell. Erratic scribbles yet sophisticated. The page is littered with cavities, where presumably the unsavory mental state of the writer made pen strokes break through the paper.
forensics: Written with heavy cursive using a light pen. The signature appears to differ from Thompson’s.
commentary: These days, any reason is a good reason.

name: Stack of Money
description: A frayed stack of cash, acclimated to frequent transportation and changing hands.
commentary: Why isn't this in a safe?

name: Whiskey Bottle
description: A tall bottle of spirits, thick and heavy. The label is new, and the whiskey is clear and golden.
forensics: This drink was laced with lethal doses of arsenic.
commentary: Jameson, as Irish as a potato famine.

name: Cigarette Stubs
description: A pack of Lucky Strike cigarettes.
forensics: These contain a standard 17 milligrams of nicotine, a healthy amount

name: Cold Soup
description: Soup with beans and rice. A hearty meal for an ordinary person.
forensics: Nothing unusual was detected. It’s just a soup can.

name: Golden Ticket Note
description: A trade deal asking Thompson about shipping rifles to the Republic of Spain. The sender's signature is illegible to the naked eye.
forensics: The handwriting is heavy cursive written using a light pen. It is signed by Lord Reynard.
commentary: Nice to see people still like to " praise the lord and pass the ammunition."
